title: Who will be elected senator from Texas in the 2018 midterm elections?
preds:
I contend Senator Ted Cruz will retain his seat in the Senate. Although Beto O'Rourke is wildly popular and a fan favorite of sorts, I do not believe he has the support in Texas to out Senator Cruz. This is interesting considering the fact that Beto O'Rourke has raised more many than any other midterm candidate. Additionally, he has made a campaign stop in every single Texas county - all 254.  That being said, it still does not appear that Beto O'Rourke will beat Senator Cruz. Cruz has never once lost his lead in the polls, in fact, he is consistently at least 6 points ahead of Beto O'Rourke. Senator Cruz has a consistent support amongst Texas voters, and it seems he will be able to retain his seat.  https://www.axios.com/midterm-candidate-fundraising-e606786d-35f8-4b29-9c5b-6ce88ab2caed.html
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/05/us/politics/midterm-elections-update.html
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/tx/texas_senate_cruz_vs_orourke-6310.html
Who knows, but early turnout suggests predictions of likely voter sample not very accurate so could well have 5% error. Momentum appears to favor O'Rourke but a low-confidence prediction.

Using the I Ching oracle (essentially a random selection)
Ted Cruz: hexagram 3, line 2 "finally gets there"
Beto O'Rourke: hexagram 54, line 6 "the basket is empty, nothing gained
RPC poll average to gaussian curve.

High rate of turnout in early voting might favour democrats
-early voting in-person vs by mail - mixed

Assuming: 
-typically low voter turnout, about 10 percent of Republicans and 7 percent of Democrats who registered to vote voted last time. -15.8 million Texans are registered to vote. 
Then: 
Republicans baseline #:1,579,326 votes (10% of the 15.8mill registered) 
Democrats baseline #: 1,105,527 votes (7% of the 15.8 mill registered). 
(*Cruz small donations average about $50, but $75 tightens the range) So can either party expect to get this baseline number of votes? Calculating the impact of the small and large individual donations for Cruz and Beto from Opensecrets. org: Assuming 
- the average small individual donation is $50; the largest is the $200 max 
- the average large individual donation is $75*; and the largest is $2700 max 
Then: 
Cruze might receive in the range of 57,507 to 394,297 votes 
Beto might receive int he range of 150,066 to 1,004,152 votes when large and small individual donations are combined. So Beto O'Rourke is still about 100,000 votes short Working against Cruze is Texans don't seem to like being bought by big money (explains a bit the chronic low voter turnout) 
Additional PAC, and undisclosed money raised: 
Cruz $1,25 Million; and 8% additional undisclosed funds totalling $2 million) 
O'Rourke $72K and 1.5% additional undisclosed funds totalling 200,000 Also working against Cruz is the fact that Trump has been vociferous in his contempt for the guy (Canadian!) He rallied for Cruz rally. But they might still vote for Cruz as a way to support Trump. Democrats are pouring money into republican strongholds to shake undecideds 
But letter bombs and caravan might have effect. (Caravan less so as southern texas counties seem pro-mexican border/ immigration ) https://www.opensecrets.org/members-of-congress/summary?cid=N00033540
https://www.opensecrets.org/members-of-congress/summary?cid=N00033085 https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2018-elections/2018/10/19/record158-million-texans-registered-vote-novembers-midterm-elections
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/texas/

Food for thought that all the top forecasters are on the opposite side of this. Phone polls don't work for me when sides are polarized. I think Texans voting for Beto might be under-represented in the poll results ...sort of a like the Brady effect but this is due to unfavourability of admitting one supports Beto in Texas. Turnout for early voting record high. High turnout, I think, favours democrats. In-person, suggests more registered democrats. As of Oct 24 about 11% vs 2% of by mail (possibly > republican) https://www.sos.state.tx.us/elections/earlyvoting/2018/oct24.shtml
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/23/us/politics/early-voting-midterms.html
Tribune polls margin of error non-apparent. "According to the newly released poll, 49 percent of respondents said they would vote for Cruz, while 44 percent said they would vote for O’Rourke; 3 percent said they would vote for someone other than O’Rourke or Cruz, and 1 percent said they wouldn’t vote. The online poll of about 2,000 Texans over the age of 18 was conducted Oct. 12-18. Ipsos online polls do not have margins of error; instead, the poll's precision is measured using a "credibility interval." This poll's credibility interval was +/-3.1 percentage points among likely voters. Other recent polls have also shown Cruz in the lead. A Quinnipiac University phone poll of 730 likely voters from earlier this month put Cruz ahead of O’Rourke by 9 percentage points." But that was a phone poll from a month ago https://www.texastribune.org/2018/10/24/Ted-Cruz-Beto-ORourke-poll/

This is probably the tightest race this election cycle.  This all depends on O'Rourke's ability to get people to the polls.  Cruz has etched out a narrow lead in recent polling.  So Texas being Texas, a deep red state, it will probably go to Cruz.  But hey, who knows what impact the recent bombings and scandals will have on Texas voters? Texas could be a big surprise.

Texas - overall - is still Texas..  Suggest that the recent CNN polls (+ 5-7 for Cruz) may be the most meaningful. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Texas,_2018#Polling_3 https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/texas/ https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/22/trump-holds-texas-rally-as-ted-cruz-tries-to-hold-off-beto-orourke.html
Well, how did I miss this one when I was doing the other Senate forecasts?  Better late than never, I guess. It's not outright impossible for O'Rourke to win, but, really.

tweet followers 650K beto; 1.14million for Cruz but every time Beto tweets, he gets thousands of retweets while Cruz only get 25 to 45 so, I think Cruz is BS'ing the followers to up his numbers and this election seems to be about independence, avoiding collusion with big business, super pacs and keeping it real for the citizens. Plus O'Rourke is young, cute and energetic and seems (from what little info I have) to actually live by  his integrity and this is gaining him momentum in terms of followers late in the race

https://twitter.com/BetoORourke/status/1050733011623337985/video/1 compared with Cruz' $10474775 small/individual conributions <$200 roughly translates to 52,374 votes If that translates to votes, it would put Beto O'Rourke in a fight with Cruz. OTOH, Cruz is almost exclusively funded by PACs. https://www.opensecrets.org/races/candidates?cycle=2018&id=TXS2&spec=N Total small and large contributions for Cruz=($10,474,775 + $13,860,149) = $24,334,924 
Total small and large contributions for Beto = ($27,488,875 +$34,078,095) = $61,566,970  2.5 ratio
adding a 5% premium due to big fundraising momentum for Beto this close to election

So much depends on voter turnout. I just read an article in a Catholic publication about voter-registration and turn-out efforts being sponsored by the Catholic church in TX.  By a small margin, Catholics voted for DJT, and tend to vote for anti-abortion candidates, but these are HISPANIC Catholics so perhaps immigration will be their dominant issue. (I noted that no-where in the article was any mention made of what issues were being highlighted in these campaigns, except the issues of responsibility for civic participation and promotion of "justice".) https://www.ncronline.org/news/politics/midterms-loom-catholics-push-higher-voter-turnout-el-paso?utm_source=Oct+17+News+Benevento+voter+registration&utm_campaign=cc&utm_medium=email Latest polls have Cruz up by 4, 5 & 7%.  . . .  Beto's latest fundraising totals were nearly 3x that of Cruz' so Beto's got the money to buy advertising to close the gap. . . . maybe . . . .
So the Irishman has raised 28 million? Says he will not share it with other campaigns. Losing friends fast now. Meanwhile the Canadian is doing what Ted does...

He's got momentum (RCP average lead is up to 7% from 4.6% on the 6th), and he's holding his own in the debates (which was the only thing that was really going to create an upset in this race).  I think he's pretty much got this tied up...

Recent polling has Cruz with a very comfortable lead, averaging polls shows him with an outright majority. This will shift with the polls. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/senate/tx/texas_senate_cruz_vs_orourke-6310.html
I think Cruz is firmly ahead now
Revised up. All of hollywoods money cant buy Texas.
I'm convinced the enhanced  turn-out for Beto will be as hard to discover as his ethnic heritage as an Irishman.

Well I hate to do this because he is terrible but Cruz is maintaining his lead in the state and given the state's fundamentals (they haven't voted for a democrat in state-wide office since 1994) I think Cruz wins in the end.
Despite pockets of Liberal voters in her major cities ("blueberries in the tomato soup"), Texas has vast rural areas, which still lean heavily republican.
I actually have felt he was going to win for many months now, despite my husband and others saying it isn't possible.
Beto running on platform to Abolish ICE. That dog wont hunt in Texas.

Uphill battle for O'Rourke. Kavanaugh confirmation also may be energizing some Republican voters at least at the moment. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-ted-cruz-will-defeat-beto-orourke-in-this-texas-senate-race-2018-10-05 https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-generic-ballot-polls/
Updating based on latest aggregation of 538 and predictit.

Suggesting that the following past incident - plus apparently questionable answers about it -  may have some weight with certain voters. No change to forecast for now: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2018/09/25/beto-orourkes-false-claim-he-did-not-try-leave-scene-dwi/ https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/texas/

Note to self: Taken from 538 senate model as it is identical to mine without having to adjust for polling bias (from here on I'll abreviate it as 538m)  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/texas/#deluxe

The press are hyping this one because they feel the need to inject suspense and excitement into their daily life, lest their readers and viewers and listeners get bored and slide away.  This happens in every election cycle, and almost always turns out to be a damp squib.

Whilst O'Rourke has run a very good campaign, I highly doubt it'll be enough to unseat Cruz. 
Cruz is well established in the state, has a decent personal record, and has been a critic of Trump.
This is reflected in the polling, which has Cruz an average of 4.5% ahead (RCP).
There are just too many Republicans in TX. However O'Rourke is running a superb race and will get within 4 points.

With all the resentments about immigration, and family separation at the boarder among the  Latino,and other minority communities in Texas. The people still believed Ted Cruz is the solution to many problems facing Texas. Ted cruz  is going to win re election, but it would be a close or tight one. Beto is a great guy and force, his messages resonate with the minority communities, they see him as that change that will not  only  impact their lives in Texas , but  also in the nation capitol. Regrettably he doesn't have enough vote to win Ted Cruz. If he did win, then it would be serendipity .
Texans love Willie Nelson! Kidding aside ... republicans don't like Cruz.   Democrats don't like Cruz.   Beto has a good vibe and stacks of money.

This race has begun to garner real national attention, which means that fundraising for O'Rourke will continue to increase because of Democratic momentum nationally. Ted Cruz, as pointed out by strategists in his own party, has likeability issues. However, I would have still put this in the GOP camp until a few days ago; First, the Kavanaugh Supreme Court debacle is very likely to intensify voter turnout on the Democratic side. If Kavanaugh is confirmed, despite the credible allegations, and given that Cruz is likely to vote for him, it will drive Democratic turnout. If he is not confirmed, chances are the President will nominate someone even more conservative, which will threaten Roe V. Wade, which would hit Texas women particularly hard, which will drive turnout. Second, Cruz is relying heavily on Trump support to get him across the finish line despite the president becoming more and more unpopular. It remains to be seen how much of an asset Trump can be in a state that is turning purple. Finally, O'Rourke is running a campaign similar to Bernie Sanders in 2016 in that it is built on authenticity and statement of views that are genuine and not poll tested. While conventional wisdom holds that O'Rourke's views are too progressive for Texas, Sanders was able to show that being honest and accepting discussions on your views with people who potentially disagree (as O'Rourke did in regards to football players kneeling) can earn respect and votes.

Polls are skewed lately.  In 2016 I was in Indiana prior to the election and thought it uncanny that there were so many Trump signs.  I was recently in Texas and saw many Beto signs.  I think there's something going on in Texas and we may be surprised.
Revising for rising numbers in 538 model, extrapolating to Nov.

Ted Cruze has likability and personality problems and the extreme Tea Party issues and fears are much less relevant now than when has was first elected to Senate.  Women and other demographics are quickly changing also;  and O'Rourkei is very viable contender.
538 predicts stronger odds for Ted Cruz than predictit: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/texas/#deluxe

Based on new polls and weighting 
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/texas/#deluxe

538 deluxe model. The deluxe takes into account expert forecasts front the Cook Political Report, among others. 538 says the deluxe model should be the most accurate.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-midterm-election-forecast/senate/texas/#deluxe
I did not know "Beto" is not even Hispanic. Cruz is. (and Canadian)

Updating +1% Cruz
New poll came out showing +2% Beto. Unfortunately, it was a very flawed, online only poll.  That is called a 'sampling error' usually caused by someone who tries to do a sampling but goes after the easiest, but non -representative sample.   A proper phone poll costs $10,000-$30,000 and there is a temptation to do online only, but good stats don't support it for these kinds of election.  In this case, the online poll would skew toward younger crowd which is more Democratic.  
Overall, the last good poll was Quinnipac's +9% for Cruz, it sampled land line and mobile phone #s, so a far more accurate snapshot of the minds of Texans. My message to all of you, do NOT trust online polls in states with large rural populations. (My Bias: Pro Beto.    My Stat package of choice:R w/ Tidyverse)

1. New poll
2. Special election result Sept 18

O'Rourke is making a bit of a splash in the polls just now.  On the other hand, answering a poll is easier than showing up to vote.   On yet another hand, I hope that eventually enough folks will fulfill their solemn civic obligation to lie to pollsters so that polls become meaningless, get discontinued, and force people to stop talking about elections as "races" so there can be actual discussion about actual issues.   One is not optimistic about this.

Subtracting 11% from previous estimate. Most recent polls do not fit the narrative that Beto is gaining ground. Quinnapac is a respected quality poll, reflecting the mind of the people as of this time. Given the scandals currently underway, it would appear very little is stirring the minds of Texan enough to push Beto to victory.

Adding +1 to Beto based on the Kavaunah hearings that touch upon sexual assault and a GOP that will likely push back on the accuser. Historically, this will anger women and drive more to vote.  This will add +1 or +2 to Beto's chances.  This also assumes the next poll is in line with past trends of Cruz gaining steam and the demographic outreach to GOP crowd via Willie Nelson.   Past analysis includes https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/770151

The last time Ted Cruz ran for Senate (2012) there were 18,279,737 people eligible to vote in Texas.  Of those, 13,646,226 were registered to vote. Votes were cast by 7,993,851 individual voters.  Thats about 59% turnout of registered voters and 44% turnout of all eligible voters.  In the 2012 general election Cruz beat Democrat Paul Sadler in a 56% to 40% decision.  Cruz received 4,440,137 vote to	Sadler's 3,194,927 votes.   Going into the 2018 election there are now 19,900,980 eligible voters in Texas (8% increase) and 15,249,541 registered voters (about 11% increase).  Thats 1,603,315 more registered voters than the last time Ted Cruz ran.  Several hundred thousand votes more than the margin by which Cruz won by in 2012.   political polling suggest that, in Texas, the number of independent voters has grown- although you cannot detect them easily from primary election data.  This surge in independent voters leans heavily in favor of the non-incumbant candidate, in this case Beto Orourke.  My forecast takes into account the possible impact of these independent voters.

Affirming forecast for now. As a challenger to an incumbent Republican in Texas (for starters), O'Rourke would appear to have the more difficult path to victory. Major political forecasting orgs. continue to project this election as "lean Republican" or similar. https://www.270towin.com/2018-senate-election-predictions/ Although he's purportedly been "open" about it, O'Rourke's old DWI arrest - now with additional alleged details made public - could be (at least close to) a disqualifier for some voters. https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/beto-orourke-reality-check/ https://www.texastribune.org/2018/09/12/analysis-ted-cruz-beto-orourke-swoon-trouble/

As of now this Senate race is a statistical dead heat (Cruz 38%, O'Rourke 37%).  However, a recent poll indicates that 57% of independent voters rate Cruz as "unfavorable".  Because the percentage of independent voters in Texas is on the rise, independent voters are likely to swing the election.  While Texas in general does lean republican, O'Rourke is a different kind of democrat and appears to resonate not only with independents, but also with moderate republican voters- particularly female republican voters.

Willie Nelson will be playing a fundraiser gig for Beto. It will be a chance to reach across and convert some Cruz supporters based on Willie's base. +1% to Beto 
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/09/14/willie-nelson-is-playing-his-first-ever-political-concert-for-beto-orourke-some-fans-are-abandoning-him/?utm_term=.cdb1ac407c43
Ted Cruz has financial backing of tea party supporter and devilish ability to create alliance even with his enemies. He may sell some of his influence to people who would eventually support him.

41 from 33 crowd already at 70-30. 
Incumbency helps but Beto is so close. Recount? 
http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/surprisingly-senate-now-play  Will go 88-12 though I really ought to be 55-45. Maybe that's what the vote count will be.

Cruz has the lead in polling and the state is Texas. O'Rourke clearly has momentum based on how polling is trending but the state is Texas. Point is I think the race will be close but inside information (polling) and outside information (Texas has a difficult to overcome republican lean) suggest Cruz will pull off a victory.
If Democrats in Texas vote O'Rourke will take it.  The question is turnout, Cruz has high negative numbers, nationwide voters want change this year.

Given the rising trend, and the continuous stream of bad news from the White House. The likelihood is high the dissatisfaction rating will nullify some of the boost Cruz will get from DJT campaigning for Cruz. Further, Cruz is now getting national attention outside of his campaign area. +5% Beto adjustment from previous estimate. 
___________________
Of the last 3 polls, Beto's spread was closing, the trend is indicating he will win. The cons of such conclusion is 1) small sample size 2) unknown composition of urban/rural as Cruz has a large rural base . 3) the Trump effect as Trump Jr and Trump will aid in the campaign. Combining the unknowns and i'll subtract 20% from a 60/40 in Beto's favorite.
Year after year stories declare some hot shot democrat was going to turn Texas blue.  Year after year they undererform their polls.  Cruz is smarmy.  And disliked.    Still not losing.

Initial forecast: Agree that "...it's Cruz's race to lose" at this point. (Ref. @Anneinak's comments below.) FWIW, Sabato's, Inside Elections, CNN, Cook (etc.) "pundit" forecasts all have this race as at least "lean Republican" at this point. https://www.270towin.com/2018-senate-election-predictions/ Early polls are fairly tight (Cruz is up), but agree O'Rourke will likely need strong (vote) turnout of supporters to have a good chance. https://www.texasmonthly.com/politics/finally-democrats-lead-texas-poll-may-not-matter/ O'Rourke reportedly is doing very well with fundraising. https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-much-trouble-is-ted-cruz-really-in/ ...As with many Senate races this year, major developments involving Donald Trump can be considered something of a 'wildcard' for this question.

Of the last 3 polls, Beto's spread was closing, the trend is indicating he will win.   The cons of such conclusion is 1) small sample size 2) unknown composition of urban/rural as Cruz has a large rural base . 3) the Trump effect  as Trump Jr and Trump will aid in the campaign.  Combining the unknowns and i'll subtract 20% from a 60/40 in Beto's favorite.

Reason:
1. Ted Cruz's lack of reaching out effort
2. Voter want to provide chance to new blood

http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/405449-five-surprises-in-midterm-fight Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D), who’s running a top-tier challenge to Sen. Ted Cruz (R) in Texas. . . 

O’Rourke’s attention-grabbing campaign has put Cruz on defense in a deep-red state that remains unfriendly territory for Democrats running statewide, despite demographics that look like the state should be moving toward the purple column.

The Democratic congressman called for Trump’s impeachment after his summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin. But arguably O'Rourke's biggest moment in the spotlight is the viral video of him defending NFL players kneeling in protest during the national anthem.

Since then, Cruz and his allies have gone on the attack — and gotten personal, with the Texas GOP tweeting O’Rourke’s mugshot from his decades-old DWI arrest. And Club for Growth is readying a seven-figure ad blitz to buoy Cruz.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Since at least the beginning of August, Cruz has topped all 7 polls, with a margin averaging over +4%.  However, the last poll shows his margin as only +1%, down from 8% & 4% on 8/21 and 8/22, respectively, so I wonder if there is momentum for O'Rourke or if the last poll was an anomaly.   I think that this election is Cruz' to lose.   Polling margins are mostly within the margin of error, but are consistent for Cruz. The generic ballot has been getting stronger for Democrats.

I am basing this on:
-Lean Republican at Cook [1] and 
-64% at Predictit [2].  [1] https://www.cookpolitical.com/ratings/senate-race-ratings
[2] https://www.predictit.org/Contract/5313/Will-Ted-Cruz-be-re-elected-to-the-US-Senate-in-Texas-in-2018#data
